rsbNotes.title: Jer 14–15
rsbNotes.text: 14:1–15:21 The people are so hardened in their sin that God will not answer even Jeremiah’s prayer for deliverance from the punishment of drought. In answer to Jeremiah’s question whether God has rejected Judah completely (14:19), God replies that the coming judgment is inevitable because of Judah’s sin, but He assures Jeremiah of personal deliverance from his enemies.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:11
rsbNotes.text: 14:11 Do not pray. See 7:16 and note. Here the prohibition follows the intercession in vv. 7–9.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:12
rsbNotes.text:
14:12 fast . . . burnt offering and grain offering. Ritual for its own sake does not move God (7:21–23 note).

sword . . . famine . . . pestilence. The first of fifteen appearances of this combination in Jeremiah (e.g., 15:2). This is a typical summation of the horrors that judgment can bring (Deut. 32:24, 25).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:13
rsbNotes.text: 14:13 the prophets. That is, those who falsely prophesy peace (6:1–4; 8:11). Jeremiah pleads on behalf of the people—that they have been misled.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:16
rsbNotes.text:
14:16 And the people. The prophet’s plea (v. 13) misses its mark: the people should have tested the prophets by their prophecies (Deut. 13:2, 3; 18:21, 22).

none to bury. See 7:33.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:19
rsbNotes.text: 14:19 We looked for peace. Because of the false prophets’ teaching (v. 13 and note).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 14:21
rsbNotes.text:
14:21 your glorious throne. The temple is in view (see 2 Kin. 19:15; but cf. 1 Kin. 8:27).

your covenant. Jeremiah recalls the covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (Gen. 15:12–21; 26:3–5; 28:13–15; Lev. 26:42–45).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:1
rsbNotes.text: 15:1 Moses and Samuel. God calls to mind two great intercessors for Israel (Ex. 32:11–14; 1 Sam. 12:23). Note also Elijah in 1 Kin. 17:1. Prayer for the people is again prohibited (7:16; 11:14), and the prayer just offered (vv. 19–22) is specifically rejected.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:3
rsbNotes.text: 15:3 sword . . . dogs . . . birds . . . beasts. See 7:33 note; 1 Kin. 21:23.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:4
rsbNotes.text: 15:4 Manasseh. A son of the reformer King Hezekiah (2 Kin. 20:21) and one of the most wicked kings. Even after the reforms of his grandson Josiah, Judah’s punishment and exile continues to be linked to him (2 Kin. 23:26). See Introduction: Author; Date and Occasion.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:6
rsbNotes.text:
15:6 going backward. See 3:22.

I am weary of relenting. Such promises as in 31:20 are for the moment in the background.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:7
rsbNotes.text: 15:7 winnowed. See 4:11, where the metaphor is used slightly differently. Here it means punishment (cf. Is. 41:16).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:9
rsbNotes.text:
15:9 who bore seven. A picture of blessing (Ps. 127:5) is reversed.

rest of them . . . to the sword. Even the remnant left by the destruction is threatened with death. Compare Is. 6:13, where a similar thought is finally softened by the promise of the “seed.”

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:12
rsbNotes.text: 15:12 Can one break iron. How could Jeremiah expect to change Judah’s stubborn heart? See 13:23 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:14
rsbNotes.text: 15:14 serve your enemies. This prophecy is fulfilled for Jeremiah at 43:4–7.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:16
rsbNotes.text:
15:16 Your words . . . I ate them. This verse recalls the sweet side of the bittersweet task of receiving God’s words (Ezek. 3:1–3).

I am called by your name. This phrase is applied to the people in 14:9.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:17
rsbNotes.text: 15:17 I sat alone. No doubt this is literally true, partly due to celibacy (16:2). But there can also be a profound sense of loneliness for the unwelcome prophet; note Elijah in 1 Kin. 19:10 and our Lord Jesus in Matt. 26:37, 38.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 15:18
rsbNotes.text:
15:18 wound incurable. The wound is Judah’s in 14:17. The whole phrase is applied to Judah in 30:12, together with a promise of healing (30:16, 17). See also 10:19, where it is used of Jeremiah.

a deceitful brook. Contrast 2:13; and cf. 20:7.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:1–17:18
rsbNotes.text: 16:1–17:18 Jeremiah is prohibited from marrying and taking part in other normal activities as a sign of coming judgment (ch. 16). A sharp contrast is drawn between the destinies of those who trust in man and in God (17:1–18).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:2
rsbNotes.text: 16:2 You shall not take a wife. The prohibition is related exclusively to Jeremiah’s role as a prophet of Judah’s fate (1 Cor. 7:26). Jeremiah will be childless, a sign that there is no immediate future for Judah.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:4
rsbNotes.text: 16:4 sword and by famine. See note 14:12.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:8
rsbNotes.text: 16:8 shall not go into . . . feasting. After v. 2 and v. 5, there is yet a third symbolic prohibition.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:9
rsbNotes.text: 16:9 silence . . . bridegroom and . . . bride. See also 7:34. Such sounds are typical of times of peace and hope (Matt. 24:38, 39; contrast 33:10, 11).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:12
rsbNotes.text: 16:12 done worse than your fathers. Though the present generation shares guilt with its forefathers (14:20), it is responsible for its own sin (31:29, 30; Ezek. 18:2–4).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:13
rsbNotes.text:
16:13 hurl you out of this land. That is, God will send them into exile (see Deut. 28:36, 64).

serve other gods. With a punishment to fit the crime, they would finally discover that these gods can provide no benefit.
